page.title: 07MACCLESFIELD CANAL
page.content: Macclesfield canal was built to connect Manchester to the Midlands and Potteries.It opened in 1831 and has twelve locks in one mile. Flooding is prevented in three different ways:- a) Simple overflow channel b) hand operated sluice c) stop-planks fitted into channels in the banks.The canal once brought coal to the silk and cotton mills from Adlington and Poynton mines, stone from Kerridge, hardware from Birmingham,Pottery from the Potteries, lime from the high peak farmers and builders, beer from Burton to Inns on its banks and wine and spirits from London. Nowadays the canal is used for pleasure cruising and one or two enthusiasts carry house - coal for local sale during the winter months.One boat is owned by a school for the handicapped and used for educational purposes.
